primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The God of Israel heals a foreign enemy (Naaman) freely through a prophet, demonstrating that divine grace is an abundant gift that cannot be monetized or controlled by religious insiders.

subject.identificatie: God (YHWH) / The Prophet Elisha (as God's agent)
tekstueel_bewijs: The God of Israel who has done the healing
He has been healed by this nobody prophet
He performed God’s grace in plenty
His flesh was restored like the flesh of a young boy
The healing is total and it is free

zender.identificatie: God (The source of life and health)
tekstueel_bewijs: The only God, the creator of heaven and earth, the restorer of life from death
The foreigner is a big-time political general
the one who came back with thanks was a Samaritan
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is warned against being the Subject (Gehazi) and invited to be the Receiver.

helper.identificatie: The Israelite Girl / The Jordan River / Naaman's advisors
tekstueel_bewijs: there is a young Israelite girl in his service
His advisors, however, persuade him to try the muddy little Jordan
helper.rol_van_god: God is the ultimate Subject; Elisha is the primary human Helper/Agent.
helper.rol_van_geest: External help through the prophetic word.

tekstueel_bewijs: He messed it all up. He is an insider to the miracle.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent represents the 'Gospel of Scarcity' which contradicts the very nature of God's character.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the church to live out of abundance rather than fear.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Church/Hearers
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon argues that because healing is free (Program 1), we are now free to give it away (Program 2).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God’s goodness is not subject to a business model
voorbeelden_mens_subject: Gehazi thinks it is worth more

voorbeelden: we are called to act faithfully
We fear others taking from us
Now I know that there is no God
the God... is the restorer of life
The former leper is free to go

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's power to heal versus man's lack of power to save himself or control the gift.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the 'Entitlement' of insiders to the 'Free Grace' of the outsider, then warns against the 'Monetization' that leads back to 'Judgment'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Grace is maintained as an absolute gift that cannot be bought, only received or rejected.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; leprosy is the physical manifestation of the spiritual state of the 'insider'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon identifies God as the only source of healing and explicitly rejects human effort or payment as a means of grace.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: We are called to act faithfully in practice and in policy

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The healing is total and it is free.
The God of Israel who has done the healing.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Characters are used as actants in a drama of grace rather than moral templates.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God saves the enemy.

identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: The hearer is moved from a false Subject position (controlling the gift) to a Receiver position.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: Strong integration of the Elisha and Jesus narratives under the theme of 'Free Gift'.
spanning_punten: The transition from the ancient story to modern 'policy' and 'neighborhood' is a slight jump in narrative level.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Restorer of life from death... God's deeds among mortals.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon implies the Spirit's work through the 'prophetic power' but doesn't name the Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is seen as the 'leprosy' of the soul that tries to own God.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the primary narrative program (Healing).

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might identify too strongly with Gehazi's greed without seeing the path back to being a 'Receiver'.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the hearer, like Naaman, is also a 'foreigner' to grace.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Devoir (Must) in the final application.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how the 'Shalom' given to Naaman actually empowers the 'giving away'.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God heals) clearly precedes Ethics (Give it away).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in structural grace; the sermon exposes the human tendency to monetize the divine while keeping God as the sovereign Subject.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric would focus on the 'insider/outsider' metaphors, Greimas reveals the 'Subject' shift from God to Gehazi.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the 2 Kings context; semiotics explains the 'engine' of the story as a conflict over the Object (Grace).
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'leprosy' at the end is a modal sanction for Gehazi's attempt to seize the Subject-role from God.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'reversal' structure typical of Greimassian narrative to highlight the scandal of grace.
